block.p: CLIMATE HELP FROM RICH NATIONS -- Foreign businesses have embraced an obscure United Nations-backed program in which businesses in wealthier nations of Europe and in Japan help pay to reduce pollution in poorer ones as a favored approach to limiting global warming. But the early efforts have revealed some hidden problems. [Page A1.]

EUROPE AIMS TO CUT EMISSIONS -- In the face of stiff opposition from the airline industry, the European Union moved forward with plans to impose charges on foreign and domestic carriers that pollute too much. ''We are showing our determination to fight climate change,'' said Europe's environment commissioner, Stavros Dimas, above, who formally announced the proposal in Brussels. [C4.]

PHONE COMPANIES GET A BOOST -- Telephone companies got some help from federal regulators in elbowing their way into the video arena that the cable industry has dominated, as the Federal Communications Commission moved to speed up the local approval process for phone companies seeking to compete. [C1.]

FORD SETTLES FOR THIRD -- The Ford Motor Company expects Toyota of Japan to unseat it for good next year as the No. 2 company in the American car market behind General Motors, a position Ford has held since the 1920s. [C1.]

WRINGING OIL OUT OF ROCKS -- The Bush administration has opened five large parcels of land in Piceance Creek Basin in Colorado for oil shale research and development projects, in yet another effort to produce oil from rocks. [C1.]

FEDEX'S PROFIT RISES -- FedEx said that second-quarter profit rose 8.5 percent because of strong global demand, but the company's forecast of earnings trailed analysts' estimates, sending its shares toward their biggest drop in four months. [C4.]

SETBACK FOR PROTECTIONISM -- European regulators overturned conditions that Spain imposed on a bid by E.On of Germany for Endesa of Spain, and they ordered Madrid to remove the hurdles by Jan. 19 or face legal action. [C4.]

EXECUTIVES CITE PAST REMARKS -- Judith Regan, the publisher who was fired last week by HarperCollins after uttering what the executives called anti-Semitic remarks, was reprimanded for making an anti-Semitic remark at work three years ago, according to two top executives at HarperCollins. [C5.]

ALTERING ADS ON THE FLY -- Commercials for Wendy's International, to be broadcast nationally on Fox Sports this weekend, are one of the earliest national examples of an emerging TV technology that allows advertisers to vary their message at the last minute using animation. The Wendy's ads will reflect events in the football games, incorporating game developments into its commercials. Advertising. [C6.]

PUBLICIS TO BUY NET MARKETER -- The Publicis Groupe, a French marketing and advertising company, said that it planned to acquire the Internet marketing specialist Digitas Inc. early next year for $1.3 billion in cash to increase its online advertising capabilities. [C6.]
INDEXES LOSE EARLY GAINS -- Wall Street finished slightly lower after investors sold shares when the major market indexes pushed through to new highs during the session. [C6.]

LILLY DISCLOSURES QUESTIONED -- For at least a year, Eli Lilly provided information to doctors about the blood-sugar risks of its drug Zyprexa that did not match data that the company circulated internally when it first reviewed its clinical trial results, according to company documents. Lilly issued a statement saying the later figures were accurate and the original information, released in February 2000, was out of context. [C1.]

PENNSYLVANIA CASINOS APPROVED -- Executives from some of the country's largest development and casino companies wept tears of joy -- and of sorrow -- as the Gaming Control Board of Pennsylvania approved five licenses for slot-machine-only casinos throughout the state. [A31.]

CVS CORPORATION WON antitrust approval from the Federal Trade Commission to purchase Caremark Rx, the pharmacy benefit manager. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
HUNTINGTON BANCSHARES of Columbus, Ohio, said it would buy another Ohio-based banking company, Sky Financial Group, in a stock and cash deal worth $3.6 billion to solidify its Midwest base. (AP)
CARMAX INC., the largest used-car dealer in the United States, said that third-quarter profit almost doubled, and it raised its full-year forecast. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
NIKE INC. CREDITED STRONGER SALES of footwear worldwide, including faster-paced growth in Asia, for an 8 percent increase in profit in its second fiscal quarter. (AP)
BED BATH & BEYOND, the home furnishings retailer, said that third-quarter profit rose 5.8 percent, helped by lower purchasing costs for some products. (BLOOMBERG NEWS)
